Overview:
Every apps are expected to integrate with other apps/services.
Apps are typically made up of Activities.

Entities:
Intent - 4 of them i.e. View, Edit, Search and Notify; its action can optionally include data

Activity - an activity is a single action with a UI that performs a specific function for the user

Services - an activity without a UI

Broadcast Receivers - receivers of intents for notifications

A filter in AndroidManifest.xml file with "android.intent.action.MAIN" and "android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" settings advertises an activity as one that initiates an application e.g.

<activity android:name=".FirstActivity" android:label="@string/app_name">
    <intent-filter>
        <action android:name="android.intent.action.MAIN" />
        <category android:name="android.intent.category.LAUNCHER" />
    </intent-filter>
...
In java, the first method invoked is onCreate()
Image: ImageView alligned right, text alligned left (Vice versa)
App Inventor (recently open sourced as at 8/2011)

Intent - an identifier to communicate purpose on the ensuing activity; can be an action name specified in android manifest file or the class name of Activity class (preferred)

Activity - a  view container class (extends Activity) - controller that own view(s)

View - view is set by setContentView() in an activity class, e.g. setContentView(R.layout.main)  which will force the runtime to look for a view defined in res/layout/main.xml resource file

Search dialog and SearchView widget delivers search queries to a specific activity that performs searches
Search dialog and SearchView widget delivers search queries to a specific activity that performs searches
Point instead of raw pixel (e.g. 1 point in iPad is 2 x 1 pixel on iPhone 4)

Density-independent pixel (dp) - for UI layout
Scale-independent pixel (sp) - for text

Instead of using pixel (px), use density pixel (dp) to support multitude of Android phones with various screen resolutions and sizes. <mark>For text, you can also use dp instead of px</mark>. I have not seen sp used for text (yet).

Also for Android 3.2 or above, please see http://developer.android.com/guide/practices/screens_support.html#DeclaringTabletLayouts
User/application level bar (Honeycomb 3.0 or above only)
iOS does not really have equivalence for this, the closest is View controller's navigation bar

2011-08-30 13:51:28.905 VideoBrowser[27268:207] *** Terminating app due to uncaught exception 'NSInvalidArgumentException', reason: '-[CustomMoviePlayerViewController setVideoFrame:]: unrecognized selector sent to instance 0x5b27b10'
*** Call stack at first throw:

It means the method does not exist!
AndroidManifest.xml (granting request access to network, camera, contacts etc)

While there is no advanced tool based connection mapping between source codes and UI controls like iOS, Android's approach is to use specially notation known as @id+ to refer to a control in main.xml. To respond to UI events, one has to add a Java class to be the event (whatever that is like onClick) listener.
Connection between the attribute of the UI controls and their corresponding IBOutlet

In a button tag inside main.xml:
...
android:id=""@+id/bAdd""

In Java:
import android.widget.Button;
...
Button button = (Button)findViewById(R.id.bAdd);
No need to do anything. By default, you can always go back (hit Back button) to the previous Activity unless you did a finish(); inside its onPause() method.

Configurable swipe event thresholds

scrollSupressionThreshold (default: 10px) – More than this horizontal displacement, and we will suppress scrolling
durationThreshold (default: 1000ms) – More time than this, and it isn’t a swipe
horizontalDistanceThreshold (default: 30px) – Swipe horizontal displacement must be more than this.
verticalDistanceThreshold (default: 75px) – Swipe vertical displacement must be less than this.

link text Pages can also be pre-fetched programmatically by calling $.mobile.loadpage( url ). Pre-fetching links will naturally cause additional HTTP requests that may never be used, so it’s important to use this feature only in situations where it’s highly likely that a page will be visited.

data-filter="true"

e.g.

      <ul id="mylist" data-role="listview" data-filter="true" data-split-theme="c">

jQueryMobile (jqm) is the coolest framework I have seen. Using just data-role as an attribute in DOM element like div, ul etc, one can magically transform existing web portal into mobile friendly portal. 

An option to selectively skip the transformation is also available using data-role="none".
